0.cdata!:
Costa Rica - Proyecto de Credito
            Agrfcola y Desarrollo

abstracts.cdata!:
This is the project completion report on
            the Agricultural Credit and Development Project in Costa
            Rica. The objectives of the project were to increase
            agricultural output, particularly beef and milk; raise
            income levels, particularly those of small and medium-size
            farms; and strengthen the extension service of the Ministry
            of Agriculture and Livestock (MAG) as well as its seed
            production capability. The project included credit for
            development of livestock, crops and agro industries; support
            for strengthening the national extension service; support
            for implementation of a seed improvement program; funds for
            a pilot scheme for the rehabilitation and maintenance of
            feeder roads; and assistance in preparation of a rural
            development project. About 1,520 sub loans were financed,
            compared with 3,260 estimated at appraisal, although the
            volume of credit disbursed almost equaled original
            expectations. Nearly 70 percent of the sub loans were for
            livestock development, 28 percent for crop development, and
            2 percent for agro industries. As stipulated in the Loan
            Agreement, small farmers accounted for more than 25 percent
            of the sub loans. Additional extension staff were hired and
            trained, but eventually most of the staff transferred to
            other positions because of better employment conditions
            elsewhere. The project's seed program component was
            restructured during implementation, and a substantial
            contribution was made to improving the seed production
            capability of the Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock. The
            feeder road component was successfully implemented, but only
            after the Bank's disbursement percentage was increased
            from 30 percent to 70 percent. The rural development study
            financed under the project was completed with much delay as
            a result mainly of changes in the Government's priorities.
